body.div1:
Letter from Walter Reed to [Jefferson Randolph Kean], April 24, 1900
Pardon this
short note,
but I damaged
a rib the other
day & can't
use my
arm very
well.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
April 24, 1900
My dear Major:
Upon
my return, I found that
the S. G. had made
his selections for the
Military Surgeon's meet-
ing in New York, & hence
it wasn't worth while
to ask him to send you
& myself. He was as
cross as a bear, when
I had my interview with
him, & hence I am glad
to say that I haven't seen
him since. He was appa-
rently disgusted over De-
Witt's return, and had just
had a telegram from Gorgas
requesting not to be sent
to Santiago, and so there was
Hell to pay & an apparent
deficiency in hot pitch!
I left as soon as I
got a chance & went
back to the joys of Elec-
trozone, once more.
My report went to Gen.
Wood, last week.
Now - 1st: Let me congrat-
ulate you on becoming
the Chief Sanitary officer
of Havana. I know that
you will win honor in
the position - 2nd. A Board
for the examination of
Enlisted men, who have
served two years, will
meet in each Dept.
on June 1st next. Law-
rence will lack 17
days of completing his
two years. I have already
seen Corbin who bluffly
referred me to Col. Carter.
The latter said, “by all means,
let your boy make out
his application and I
think that we can make
it alright for him”. But
as I haven't a particle
of confidence in either of
these “C.s,” I am going to
ask you to mention the
case to Gen. Lee. This Ex-
amination is held in place
of the Septr examination, &
unless the boy can come
up in June, he'll have
to wait till next year.
Appointments are to be
made July 1st. Lawrence's two
years expire June 17th 1900. With much love to you and
your dear wife & a kiss for
little Martha, affectionately,
yours,
Reed.
